Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Magnetic Directed Alignment of Injectable Neural Stem Cell Scaffold for Regeneration After Spinal Cord Injury

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1134119 / 1134449
Liu / Cao

The research objective of this award is to develop a novel technique to fabricate injectable, alignable, and bioactive scaffold that uses neural stem cells (NSCs) as building blocks for spinal cord injury (SCI) repair. This work capitalizes on the ability to manipulate superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIONs) with magnetic field remotely and noninvasively. In this approach, the NSCs are labeled with nanoengineered cationic magnetoliposomes (CMLs) which encapsulate numerous SPIONs, and can be injected into the injured spinal cord in colloidal suspensions. Upon the application of a magnetic field, magnetically labeled NSCs will spontaneously self-assemble into chain/column lattices and align along a virtual axis that is defined by the field flux lines, thereby forming a scaffold to guide the directional regrowth of axons. Neurotrophic factors stored in the bilayer of the CMLs can be released by radio frequency electromagnetic triggering to promote NSC survival and axonal growth.

If successful, this research will transform state-of-the-art of biological scaffold fabrication in tissue engineering, when directional guidance is desired for cellular growth and expansion, and enhance the therapeutic strategies for challenging issues of experimental spinal cord injury and neurodegenerative diseases. This work will also help to greatly expand the use of SPIONs in general clinical applications by changing their role from passive tracer (e.g., magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) contrast agents) to active enabler of biological processes. The technology developed can be conveniently translated to clinical treatments of a diverse group of nervous system diseases, such as traumatic brain injury (TBI) and peripheral nerve disorders. It will benefit hundreds of thousands of Americans who are have severely limited mobility or paralyzed incurring from these diseases. Additionally, this work investigates the magnetic directed self-assembly of soft biological particles under histological conditions, and the findings will advance fundamental understanding of aggregation kinetics and phase separation in dipolar colloids, which constitutes the basis of a variety of micro/nanofluidic applications. Through the proposed project, an integrated interdisciplinary research and education program will be established which creates vast opportunities for underrepresented groups, by actively recruiting qualified minority students for both undergraduate and graduate studies and by engaging in K-12 teacher/student outreach activities.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HEALTH SCIENCE CENTER AT HOUSTON, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of Texas Health Science Center Houston

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating event that results in enormous physical and emotional suffering in patients. SCI patients often live with paralysis and extremely reduced quality of life and productivity. Therapeutic intervention(s) that would restore even partial function would significantly increase the quality of life of those patients. Unfortunately, the effective treatments are currently not available for SCI-triggered sensory and motor impairments primarily due to the lack of successful strategies being optimally developed to promote long distance axonal regeneration. Most axons in the adult mammalian CNS fail to regenerate after injury. This has been attributed not only to the intrinsic indolence of the mature neurons but also to the non-permissive environment encountered by the injured axons. Transplanted neural stem cells (NSCs) have shown great promise to promote axonal regeneration and functional recovery after SCI by multiple mechanisms, such as providing permissive substances for axonal growth, secreting the growth factors. In this study, we attempted to further enhance the therapeutic potential of NSC for SCI by developing a novel technique to fabricate injectable, alignable, and bioactive scaffolds for axonal regeneration that use neural stem cells (NSCs) as the building blocks.  Our results show that patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have been successfully developed from skin fibroblasts of SCI patients. Importantly, we have established protocols to induce and purify NSCs from human iPSCs. These patient-specific NSCs can survive and differentiate into both neurons and glial cells after transplantation into a rat SCI models. Furthermore, we have synthesized iron oxide nanoparticles (SPIONs) and cationic magnetoliposomes (CMLs) in house and labeled NSCs with CMLs in vitro. More importantly, magnetic field can remotely and invasive control the alignment of NSCs in vitro. These results serve as a proof of concept that combination of magnetically labeled NSCs with controllable magnetic field can construct an injectable, alignable and bioactive NSC scaffolds, which could be more efficiently promote axonal regeneration and functional recovery after SCI. New technology is needed to apply the magnetic field in vivo. If successful, our study could greatly advance the neural stem cell-based cell therapy in clinical treatments of SCI and other neurological diseases.


Last Modified: 02/22/2016
Modified by: Qi L Cao

SCI patients often live with paralysis and extremely reduced quality of life and productivity. Therapeutic intervention(s) that would restore even partial function would significantly increase the quality of life of those patients. Most axons in the adult mammalian CNS fail to regenerate after injury. New technology is needed to apply the magnetic field in vivo. If successful, our study could greatly advance the neural stem cell-based cell therapy in clinical treatments of SCI and other neurological diseases. Last Modified: 02/22/2016 Submitted by: Qi L Cao
